The foundations of quantum mechanics are a major open problem in the history of science. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is a significant advance in the history of quantum foundations, and it may lead to a resolution of the foundations problem.

This is a study of the molecular mechanism of the action of a drug.

This study shows that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in the future, and that this increase will be larger in the tropics than in the temperate zones. This will have important consequences for the stability of global grain trade and for the livelihoods of the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. It will also have implications for the stability of global food prices, which are already highly variable. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are better able to cope with the heat that is becoming more prevalent in the tropics.
This is a study on the diet of large mammals, but it is not a study on the diet of large mammals.

This paper provides a snapshot of the financial health of small businesses in the United States during the COVID-19 pandemic. We find that many small businesses are financially fragile, and that many more are at risk of closing. However, the majority of businesses plan to apply for government funding.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of the smaller particles by a combination of processes that are yet to be discovered. This work is of fundamental importance to understand the nature and the significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for the study of the formation of other planetary systems. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for the study of the formation of other planetary systems.

This paper provides a comprehensive picture of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its impact on the marine environment. It shows that the global fleet has doubled in size since 1950, with the motorized fleet increasing by a factor of 10. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since the 1950s, indicating that the global fisheries are being overexploited. The paper also shows that the global fleet is stabilizing, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. However, the rate of expansion is still high, and the global fleet could increase by a further million vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would have a significant impact on the sustainability of the global fisheries.
This is a study on the effect of domestication and allomaternal care on the reproductive output of mammals.
This is a study of the importance of the timing of the introduction of a drug in the treatment of a disease.
This is a study of the structure and function of the vascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are needed by many different stakeholders. We describe the design and operation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID-19 activity, including many auxiliary indicators that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic, and for augmenting traditional public health reporting. The API and accompanying software are available for use by the public. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to many stakeholders in the fight against COVID-19.
This is a study of the structural and functional coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels.
This is a study of the potential of anaerobic fungi to produce natural products.
This is a study on the role of the brain in social behavior.

This work is about the design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable responses. It is about the synthesis of materials and structures to achieve specific responses, and the fabrication of the designed devices. It is about the design of devices that can be navigated in a situation-specific manner.
This is a study of the role of a gene in the development of a disease.
This is a study of the role of lipid metabolism in cancer.
This is a study of the effects of a class of drugs on the body.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and was the first plan to use the concept of ecosystem management. We show that the NWFP has had a significant effect on the conservation of birds, but that the effects have been uneven across ecosystems. The NWFP has halted clearcutting on federal land, but has not yet been sufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. View Full-Text

We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and can be used in a wide range of problems.
This paper is a contribution to the debate on the role of climate in human evolution. It is a study of the past, but the results are relevant to the present.
This is a study of the effects of a specific type of electronic device on sleep.
This is a study of the impact hypothesis for the Younger Dryas cooling.
This is a study on the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetles, including the impact of herbivory on beetle diversification, remains poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive view of the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impact of plant feeding on beetle diversification. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in the presence of angiosperms, and that the evolution of plant-feeding habits, including the acquisition of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls, triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles.

This is a study on the development of a deep learning algorithm for the optimization of antibodies. The algorithm is used to improve the binding affinity of an antibody to multiple variants of SARS-CoV-2. The algorithm can be used to optimize the binding affinity of other protein molecules in the future.

This is a study of the evolution of technology, and the role of social learning in that evolution. It is a large-scale experiment in which the effect of population size on the evolution of technology was manipulated. The results suggest that larger populations do not enhance the evolution of technology via cumulative cultural evolution.
This is a study of the role of APOE in the function of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious regions in the Earth, and its formation mechanism is still a mystery. This work provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core.

This is a study of the effects of a drug that is commonly used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) on the brain of people who use marijuana. The study shows that the brain’s response to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in people who use marijuana. This finding is consistent with the idea that the brain’s response to MP is a marker of the reactivity of the brain to DA stimulation.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the human brain is uniquely adapted to process language. This paper provides evidence that the human brain is also uniquely adapted to process language by revealing the computational mechanisms that underlie language comprehension in the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be used in scientific computing, where the accuracy of the solution is crucial. We show that, in some cases, the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) does not imply the existence of an algorithm that can compute such a NN. This is a fundamental result that has important implications for the use of DL in scientific computing. We also introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), that is stable and can compute stable NNs with a small number of layers. This algorithm is a significant step toward the use of DL in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a case study in the failure of science communication. The study of exponential growth, which is the basis of the pandemic’s severity forecasts, is often cited as an example of the public’s inability to understand exponential growth. However, the study’s design is flawed in a way that is rarely acknowledged. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years, and has been the subject of much study. However, the causative agent has remained a mystery until now. This study provides the first genome sequence of a leprosy pathogen and reveals that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions.

The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a central theme in the field of quantum many-body physics. In this work, we provide a complete description of the evolution of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit. Our result is based on the integrability of the model and the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum many-body systems and opens the way to the study of the interplay between entanglement and thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems.
This is a study on the development of a vaccine for COVID-19.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, is one of the most important pandemics in human history. The transmission of the disease is still a matter of debate, with different hypotheses for the role of rats, rodents, and fleas. Here, we present a model for the transmission of plague by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results suggest that human ectoparasites were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death, ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study contributes to the understanding of the history of plague and its impact on human societies.

This study is a major contribution to the field of comparative neurobiology. It provides a detailed picture of the evolution of brain size and neuron numbers in amniotes, which is a group of animals that includes birds and mammals. The results show that the evolution of brain size and neuron numbers is not only a function of body size but also of the nature of the animal’s life history. This is important for understanding the evolution of animal cognition, which is a function of the nature of the animal’s life history.
This is a study of the role of a mitochondrial protein in the regulation of metabolism and cell behavior.
This is a study on the action of a protein in a cell.
This is a study of the effects of glucose and fructose on brain and behavior.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the settlement history of Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is also reflected in the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island, which is not homogeneous. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. View Full-Text

This work is about the influence of others on our emotions. It is about the power of the example, and the power of the example in the digital age. It is about the influence of others on our emotions, and the influence of others on our behavior. It is about the power of the example in the digital age.
This is a study of the impact of a modification on the translation of mRNA.

This is a study of the importance of a sense of meaning in life for health and well-being in older age. The results suggest that a sense of meaning in life is a key factor in the maintenance of health and well-being in older age.

This is a study of the evolution of body size in mammals. It is a quantitative analysis of the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals, and it is a quantitative analysis of the evolution of body size in mammals in general.
This is a study on the molecular mechanisms of the cold adaptation of viruses.
This is a study on the role of the environment in the life of a bacterium.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global risk of pesticide contamination of surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.
This is a study of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the deer population in the United States.

This paper is about the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.
This is a study on the role of the brain in the immune system.

This paper is of interest to a broad audience of archaeologists and anthropologists, as it provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken. It is of particular interest to those interested in the history of animal domestication, as it provides evidence for the earliest known evidence of economic exploitation of chickens.
This is a study of the folding of a large protein.
This is a study on the role of a protein in the degradation of RNA.
This is a study of the importance of arginine in the immune system.

We provide a census of the biomass of the kingdoms of life, which is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all animals in the ocean.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it exhibits a scaling limit with a nontrivial, continuous, fractal-like phase space. This is a continuous model in contrast to all known models of SOC, and it is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and present a toy model for the continuous case.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to external factors, such as strain, pressure, and temperature. In this work, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, without phonon instability, through strain engineering. This work provides a new approach to tailoring the electronic and optical properties of diamond, and it can be extended to other materials. This work also provides a new perspective on the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of materials. This work can be extended to other materials, and it can be used to explore the relationship between the electronic and phonon structures of materials. This is a study of the proteome of the sperm of Drosophila. It is a study of the life history of the sperm proteome, and it is a study of the extent of intersexual continuity in the sperm proteome.
This is a study of the fundamental physics of a biological system.

This is a study of the human virome, the set of viruses that are associated with the human body. It is a large-scale effort to characterize the human virome, and to use the data to understand the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing demonstrates the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. Thus, the HSRL is expected to be a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. (Abridged)

This is a study of the structure and function of a potassium channel.
This is a study of the interaction between a parasite and its host.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum science. It is a promising platform for the development of new technologies. However, the electronic and optical properties of diamond are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that the electronic and optical properties of diamond can be controlled by strain engineering. This opens up new possibilities for the development of diamond-based devices and materials.
This is a study on the impact of low humidity on the outcome of influenza infection.

This is a study of the brain in action. It provides a glimpse into the workings of the human brain, and in particular the language system, by using intracranial recordings to investigate the neural basis of language.
This is a study on the regulation of gene expression and protein degradation.
This is a study of the brain, and the brain is a very complex system.
This is a study on the interaction between plants and bacteria.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.
This is a study of the evolution of the sense of hearing. It is a study of the evolution of the sense of hearing in spiders.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing anthropogenic particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

This study provides a proof of concept for the use of recombinant proteins as a platform for the development of vaccines against COVID-19. The engineered protein is easy to express in bacteria, and the VLPs can be produced in insect cells. The protein is also immunogenic in mice, and the VLPs can be used as a vaccine. The engineered protein and VLPs can be used as a platform for the development of vaccines against other viruses.
This is a study on the role of a protein in development.

This is a study of the history of plague, one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It is also a study of the history of the human species, as plague has been a constant threat to human populations for millennia.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. This study provides a comprehensive assessment of the effects of soil health management practices on soil organic carbon storage in a long-term field experiment. The results provide a strong basis for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices that can be implemented on a global scale.

This work is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. The SpillOver platform can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.
This is a study on the evolution of a trait in plants, and the role of animals in the evolution of that trait.

This study provides a unique insight into the genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period. The results indicate that the genetic structure of the population in the late 5th/early 6th century AD was very complex, with a high degree of heterogeneity in the genetic ancestry of the population. In addition, the results indicate that the genetic structure of the population in the late 5th/early 6th century AD was very complex, with a high degree of heterogeneity in the genetic ancestry of the population.
This is a study on the evolution of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5, and their potential to cause cross-species transmission.

This is a study of the value of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform in the context of a resource-limited setting. The study shows that the platform is able to identify a broad range of pathogens, including vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, and that the platform can be used to identify the most likely pathogens in undifferentiated febrile illness. The study also shows that the platform can be used to identify the most likely pathogens in undifferentiated febrile illness. The study also shows that the platform can be used to identify the most likely pathogens in undifferentiated febrile illness.
This is a study on the structure and function of a key enzyme in the human genome.
This paper is a contribution to the field of the origin of life. It is a review of the current state of the art in the field, and it provides a summary of the current state of the art in the field.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

This is a study on the efficacy of tocilizumab in the treatment of severe and critical patients with COVID-19. The results show that tocilizumab can improve the clinical condition of patients immediately, and the mortality can be reduced.
This is a study on the role of a natural product in the interaction of fungi with other fungi and bacteria.
This paper is a contribution to the understanding of the origin of the surface of Mars.

This study provides a global perspective on the impact of late-spring frosts on forest ecosystems and the vulnerability of forests to increasing frost frequencies. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not well suited to the new frost regimes. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.
This is a study of the immune system in the gut, and the role of the immune system in the development of inflammatory bowel disease.
This is a study on the use of human induced pluripotent stem cells in the study of ALS.
This is a study of the role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious disease.
This paper is of interest to a general audience of evolutionary biologists and ornithologists.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.
This is a study on the evolution of the green color of animals.
This is a study of the role of a gene in cancer.
This is a study of the history of science, technology, and medicine, and it is also a study of the history of the Bible.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction and recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is based on five ash beds, each of which is interpreted as a deposition of a volcanic ash cloud. The age model is consistent with the timing of the extinction and the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This work provides a new time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the timing of recovery of the ecosystem. (Less)
This is a study on the role of a transcription factor in the development of a disease.

This is a study of the structure of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. The structure of the spike protein is important for understanding the virus and for the development of vaccines and drugs to treat the disease.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 83.18 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.
This is a study of the chemical behavior of the elements under pressure. It is a study of the chemical behavior of the elements under pressure.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been important in shaping the fire regime in the past and will continue to be so in the future. However, the effect of these on the global carbon cycle is uncertain, and we find that changes in climate are more important in driving warming. Our results suggest that climate change may be offsetting some of the warming caused by human activities, and that the effect of human ignitions and fire suppression on the carbon cycle is more uncertain than previously thought. This has implications for the future of the global carbon cycle and the climate.
This is a study on the role of glycans in the symbiosis between a squid and its luminescent symbiont.

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. This method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, and it is applicable to many domains. We illustrate the method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method provides a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. We believe that this method will be useful for many researchers in the social sciences and humanities.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating pandemics in human history. It is generally assumed that the bacterium Yersinia pestis was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. However, this assumption is based on a single source of evidence, which is the tree-ring record of the region of Central Europe. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This suggests that the introduction of the disease into Europe was not a single event, but rather a series of introductions, which may have been delayed by several years. This has important implications for the understanding of the history of the plague pandemic in Europe.
This is a study on the role of viruses in the ecology of a marine ecosystem.
This is a study on the use of antibodies in the treatment of leukemia.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. It is the only place in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only place in the world where the Bantu language family is spoken. This paper provides a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, and it provides a unique opportunity to study the impact of the human colonization of the island on the present genomic diversity.
This is a study of the role of a small RNA in the regulation of metabolism.

This is a study on the development of a deep learning algorithm for the optimization of antibodies. The algorithm is used to improve the binding affinity of an antibody to multiple variants of SARS-CoV-2. The algorithm can be used to optimize the binding affinity of other protein molecules in the future.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information for monitoring crop status and predicting crop yields. However, the data are subjective and categorical, and thus difficult to use in quantitative applications. We show how to transform the original data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we demonstrate how the resulting index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of crop expert surveys to provide a more accurate and timely picture of crop status and yield prospects, and thus contribute to a more efficient and sustainable agriculture.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms. Here we propose a model of language that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neurons. This is a mechanism that is not unique to language and may be found in other domains of cognition.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

This is a study on the evolution of the plastid genome, which is the genetic material of the photosynthetic cells of plants. It is also the genetic material of the algae, which are the food source for many animals. This study is important because it shows that the evolution of the plastid genome is not a simple process of random changes, but is instead shaped by the environment in which the organism lives.

This study provides a unique perspective on the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought in Cape Town. It also provides a tool for the assessment of the risk of future droughts in SSA. The results are of relevance to water managers, policy makers, and the general public.
This paper is a contribution to the history of science, and to the history of the world.
This is a study of the evolution of a biological pathway.
This is a study of the role of ASK1 in the development of EAE.

We find that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is due to human activities. This finding has important implications for the future of California and the rest of the world.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we identified a converging function of the autism-risk genes in Drosophila, which is the ability to activate Rac1-dependent forgetting. This finding provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work is the first to report on the extent and nature of negativity biases in a large, cross-national sample of the public. It also provides the most comprehensive demonstration of individual-level variation in the extent of these biases to date. The results have implications for the study of the psychology of news consumption, and for the design of news content and news environments. They also have implications for the study of the psychology of political behavior, and for the study of the relationship between the media and political conflict.
This is a study on the function of the CRAC channel, which is involved in a variety of physiological and pathological processes.
This is a study of the spread of disease in the brain.
This is a study on the role of bats in the emergence of viruses and the potential of MTX as a therapeutic agent.
This is a study of the role of one-carbon metabolism in cancer.
This is a study of the causes of death in the United States.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to be of interest to researchers in many-body physics, atomic physics, and photonics.
This paper is of interest to researchers in the fields of paleontology, botany, and evolution.
This is a study of the evolution of a virus that is ubiquitous in the human population.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This result is important for the credibility of climate models and for the ability of decision makers to plan for the impacts of sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly experience of life. In this paper, we show that, in America today, pain is less common in the elderly than in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class life for those experiencing pain. If this erosion continues, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.
This paper is a review of the work of a student in the laboratory.
This is a study of the use of a drug in the treatment of a disease.
This is a study on the role of the glycans that animals secrete in the development of their symbiotic relationships.

This work is about the importance of relationships in schools, and the importance of teachers’ mindsets about discipline. It is also about the importance of the people who teach us, and the importance of the people who govern us.
This is a study on the impact of alkylation on the fidelity of transcription.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe disease in humans. This study provides a detailed analysis of the role of the spike (S) glycoprotein in the infection of human cells. The results suggest that the sequential proteolysis of the S proteins is a determinant of the host range of MERS-CoV.

This is a study of the impact of a simple change to catering practices on meal selection in a university cafeteria. It is a contribution to the growing literature on the use of “nudging” techniques to influence people’s decisions in the physical environments in which they make decisions. The results suggest that it is possible to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a cafeteria by 60% without a detectable rebound effect. This has important implications for the health of the population, the environment, and the profitability of catering operations.

This is a study of the cell surface proteome, the surfaceome, in cancer. It is a systems-level view of the surfaceome in cancer, and the results suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery.

This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of universal vote-by-mail on the 2016 presidential election. We find that universal vote-by-mail did not affect either party’s share of turnout, did not affect either party’s vote share, and modestly increased overall average turnout. These findings are consistent with the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that is likely to be cost-effective in terms of increasing turnout. Our findings also suggest that the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout are likely to be small, and that the effects of vote-by-mail on the distribution of votes are likely to be small or nonexistent.
This is a study of the structure and function of a protein that is rapidly evolving and may be involved in the immune evasion and spread of the COVID-19 disease.
This is a study of the effects of hypoxia on the brain.

We live in an era of big data. This is a blessing and a curse. On the one hand, we have access to more data than ever before. On the other hand, the tools for analyzing these data are also more sophisticated. This article describes a new approach to analyzing big data that is based on the idea of “selective inference.” This is the idea that, because we have already found the strongest associations, we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. We illustrate the use of this approach in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.
This is a study of the development of the vascular system in the human body.
This is a study on the function of a protein that is not part of the human body.
This is a study on the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion.
This is a study on the packaging of the influenza virus.
This is a study of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerosis.

Wildfires are a natural and important part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.
This is a study on the molecular mechanism of the action of natural repellents on arthropods.
This is a study of the spread of a virus in a population. It is a mathematical model of the spread of Zika virus in the human population.

Coral reefs are the most diverse and productive ecosystems on the planet. However, they are also among the most threatened ecosystems on Earth. This is due to a combination of anthropogenic and natural stressors, which have led to the widespread breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the processes that are involved in the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help to identify potential targets for the conservation of coral reefs.
This is a study on the role of the microbiome in the development of cancer.
This is a study of the role of a specific receptor in the development of breast cancer.

We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation at the end of the last ice age is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and changes in climate and circulation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which is the first of its kind. Our data reveal that freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that they are particularly important in regions where alternative sources of nutrition are scarce. Our analysis also highlights the importance of river ecosystems for biodiversity conservation, as fishing pressure is most intense in regions where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of freshwater fisheries, and to assess the impacts of climate change on the sustainability of these important resources.

This work is devoted to the development of inherently safe energy devices, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are a promising candidate for this purpose. However, the development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new perspective for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
This is a study on the regeneration of the nervous system.

This is a study of the distribution of recombination events in a plant genome. It is a contribution to the understanding of the evolution of recombination in eukaryotes, and it provides a model for the study of recombination in a flowering plant.
This is a study of the brain in health and disease, using a method that is noninvasive and nonionizing.
This is a study of the structure and function of a molecule that is not yet well understood.
This is a study of the role of epigenetic changes in the development of diabetes complications.
This is a study on the role of a protein in cancer.

This is a study of the role of the microbiota in the development of alcohol dependence. The results suggest that the microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.
This is a study on the biosynthesis of a natural product, and the results are of interest to a broad audience.
This is a study on the impacts of climate change on biodiversity.
This is a study of the organization of the grid cell network in the entorhinal cortex.
This is a study on the interaction of two plants, which is of interest to both plant scientists and to people interested in the evolution of parasites.
This is a study of the brain, but it is also a study of the power of modern microscopy to reveal the structure and function of the brain.

We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of how connected they feel. This finding has implications for our understanding of the nature of social connection, the evolution of human communication, and the design of social technologies.

This is a study of the heart, but it is also a study of the brain. It is a study of the relationship between the brain and the heart, and it is a study of the relationship between the brain and the rest of the body.
This is a study on the interaction between silicon and jasmonate in the context of insect herbivory.
This is a study on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of macrophages.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms. Here we propose a model of language that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neurons. This is a mechanism that is not specific to language and may be relevant to other domains of cognition.
This is a study on the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

This is a study of the importance of small tributaries in the delivery of nutrients to large water bodies. It is a snapshot of the nutrient inputs from all tributaries of Lake Michigan, the world’s fifth largest freshwater lake by volume. The study reveals the importance of small tributaries in the delivery of nutrients to the lake, and the importance of these nutrients in the formation of algal blooms in the nearshore zone.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a strong external forcing. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the external forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a strong external force, and it is a consequence of the interplay between the network dynamics and the external forcing.
This is a study of the effects of a drug on the brain.
This paper is a contribution to the understanding of the Earth system and its response to abrupt climate changes.

This is a study of the impact of a certification scheme on deforestation. It is a very important contribution to the literature, and it is well done. However, it is not yet ready for publication in Nature. The results are interesting, and the conclusions are well justified. The methods are sound. The writing, however, is not. There are a number of problems that need to be addressed before the paper is ready for publication.
This is a study on the regulation of the exocytosis process, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms.
This is a study of the evolution of sex determination in fish.
This is a study of the role of iron in the retina.
This is a study on the evolution of specialization in a group of animals.
This paper is of interest to researchers in the fields of human evolution, anatomy, and biomechanics.
This is a study of the role of metabolism in cancer.

This study provides evidence of the impact of deforestation on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study also provides a proof of concept for the use of causal inference methods in the social sciences.

This paper is about the impact of mechanization on the sustainability of agriculture. It is about the consequences of the increasing weight of farm machinery on the soil. It is about the need to rethink the design of farm machinery in order to reduce subsoil compaction. It is also about the impact of mechanization on the environment, and the need to rethink the use of fossil fuels in agriculture.
